aphorisms: The will is the inner essence of everything.
The world is my representation.
The will is a blind striving without knowledge.
The intellect is the servant of the will.
Our body is the objectification of the will.
Life is the manifestation of an insatiable will to live.
Everything that exists is a phenomenon of will.
Individuality is an illusion created by space and time.
The will is without end or aim, hence the source of suffering.
Only by denying the will can peace be found.
Life is a constant oscillation between pain and boredom.
Suffering is the essence of life.
Every satisfaction is merely the starting point for a new desire.
Existence is a mistake to be rectified through negation.
Optimism is a mockery of human suffering.
The pain of life outweighs its pleasure.
The wise man seeks not happiness, but the absence of suffering.
Hope is the confusion of the desire for a thing with its probability.
The world is hell, and men are on the one hand the tormented souls and on the other the devils.
The denial of the will is the only salvation from the suffering of life.
Compassion is the true basis of morality.
To harm another is to harm oneself in another form.
Justice flows from compassion, not from contracts.
Kindness is the highest virtue.
The good man sees all beings as one and the same in essence.
Morality cannot be taught; it must arise from inner feeling.
True virtue consists in a denial of the will and ego.
Egoism is the original sin of the human condition.
The less we demand from others, the freer and more peaceful we become.
Pity is the only genuine moral motive.
Art is the only true and pure form of metaphysical knowledge.
In aesthetic contemplation, we escape the will.
The beauty of art lies in its ability to make us forget ourselves.
Music is the highest form of art, a direct copy of the will.
The genius is he who forgets himself in the object of contemplation.
Through the sublime, we rise above the world of striving.
The artist sees the Platonic Ideas behind appearances.
True art removes the viewer from the suffering of the world.
Only in art can we glimpse a world without desire.
Beauty is the sensory appearance of the eternal.
Man is fundamentally selfish, and only rarely selfless.
A man can do as he wills, but not will as he wills.
People are often more guided by vanity than reason.
Most people take the limits of their vision for the limits of the world.
We are rarely rational, mostly creatures of impulse.
Men are like porcupines seeking warmth—too close and they prick each other.
Human behavior is governed more by illusion than insight.
People admire intelligence in others but reward conformity.
Our actions are more the result of temperament than principle.
Man is the animal that makes suffering his own.
Talent hits a target no one else can hit; genius hits a target no one else can see.
The intellect is a tool of the will, not its master.
Reading is thinking with someone else's head.
Books are only a substitute for one's own thoughts.
The wise man is one who reflects more than he reads.
A great mind is like a solitary mountain peak.
True understanding arises from inner vision, not instruction.
Knowledge divorced from character is worthless.
Much learning does not make a wise man.
Clarity is the mark of genuine understanding.
A man can be himself only so long as he is alone.
Solitude is the fate of all great souls.
The more a man has in himself, the less he needs from others.
Happiness belongs to the self-sufficient.
Noise is the enemy of deep thought.
The greatest minds are those most alienated from the crowd.
To live alone is the destiny of all truly gifted minds.
Silence is the element in which great things fashion themselves.
Withdraw into yourself—as far as your own heart can go.
One must learn to endure being alone, or never learn to live.
Love is the will to life trying to perpetuate itself.
Romantic love is nature’s trick to ensure reproduction.
Sexual desire is the strongest expression of the will to life.
Men fall in love through illusion; women through instinct.
Woman is by nature meant for the propagation of the species.
In love, the individual serves the species.
Passion blinds the intellect and awakens the will.
The sexual instinct is irrational and tyrannical.
Women’s love is more practical; men’s more idealistic.
Beauty attracts the will to procreate.
The majority is always wrong.
Public opinion is the worst of tyrants.
The world is governed by appearances and illusion.
Most people are so opinionated because they are not truly informed.
Society rewards mediocrity and punishes excellence.
Politeness is the superficial adornment of mutual indifference.
All truth passes through three stages: ridicule, opposition, acceptance.
Education often crushes originality.
Culture is not memorization, but reflection.
The man of society must be superficial; the thinker must be profound.

subject.theme: Death and the Meaning of Life
aphorisms: Death is the real inspiring genius of philosophy.
Life is a loan from death.
The fear of death is the root of all religion.
To live is to suffer; to survive is to find meaning in suffering.
Death is the return to the state before we were born—nonbeing.
The wise man accepts death as the natural end of striving.
The will to live fears its own cessation above all.
Only he who has conquered the fear of death is truly free.
Death is the great equalizer of all illusions.
To philosophize is to learn how to die.
